name: Al-Furqaan Foundation
mission: To inform and educate all the residents of the United States the truth about Islam and its core principals and to counter the negative media information...

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Asnaf: fi_sabilillah (+5)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.evidence: Niche cause: RELIGIOUS_CULTURAL (+4); Serves underserved populations (+3)
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 31/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, religious cultural cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Track and report beneficiary counts to enable cost analysis
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with causal pathway
components.name: Theory of Change

judge_issues.message: The rationale mentions "solid working capital" as a strength, but the impact score component 'Financial Health' is 0/7 due to excessive working capital. This is a contradiction.
The rationale mentions "exceptional financial efficiency" as a strength, but the impact score component 'Governance' is 0/2 due to a weak board. This is a contradiction.

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: AL-FURQAAN FOUNDATION earns 44/100 due to good alignment and moderate impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: On their donation page, there is an option to select 'Zakat/Sadaqa'. Additionally, the 'Furqaan Project' page explicitly states, 'Donate your zakat today'. Masjid Furqaan, a division of Al-Furqaan Foundation, also has a 'Zakat Distribution' page detailing zakat and its importance. (Source: https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQGcmEHFkhw41ufXUMJ3Ytm6JbzZLzLguxXllCKxNZ_UPn0eu4CTSJ6IJEnZBKMOTnJGeif--qxTqgPwA3upsUmHLexMAdKqAa3YUkQ8V3CX)

all_citations.claim: The foundation operates the Furqaan Project and maintains a program expense ratio of 89.3%.
The organization reported total revenue of $3,249,437 and holds 25.1 months of working capital.
Audited financials confirm the value of book distribution and a fundraising efficiency of $0.01 per $1 raised.
The organization provides various online products and operates the Furqaan Dawah Center to educate the public on Islam.
The foundation is zakat-eligible and provides multiple donation options for supporters.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The foundation earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial efficiency and solid working capital, balanced against a need for more robust external impact data.
areas_for_improvement: Limited third-party impact verification for long-term educational outcomes
Need for increased transparency regarding specific beneficiary reach across all digital products

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization shows a medium donor fit for those prioritizing religious and cultural education, specifically within the American Muslim community [4]. Its status as zakat-eligible aligns with traditional Islamic giving requirements, though the urgency is categorized as religious-cultural rather than immediate humanitarian relief [5].
dimension_explanations.impact: The foundation demonstrates a capacity-building approach by offering various online products and distributing religious literature to fulfill its mission [3][4]. While it maintains a high program expense ratio of 89.3% and total revenue of $3,249,437, the direct cost per beneficiary is not fully disclosed in available filings [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: Al-Furqaan Foundation is a religious non-profit dedicated to educating the American public about the core principles of Islam through large-scale distribution of literature and community outreach.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 89.3%, indicating the vast majority of funds go directly to educational initiatives
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.01 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity position with 25.1 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: Established to counter negative media narratives, the foundation operates key programs including the Furqaan Project, Furqaan Dawah Center, and The Clear Islam [1][4]. The organization is recognized as zakat-eligible, offering donors various methods to contribute toward its mission of informing the United States about Islamic truths [5].

all_citations.claim: Furqaan Project and The Clear Islam
all_citations.quote: Programs: Furqaan Project, Furqaan Dawah Center, The Clear Islam

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The foundation earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial efficiency and solid working capital, balanced against a need for more robust external impact data.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently operates with a <cite id="2">board size of only 2 members</cite>, which is below standard recommendations for independent oversight.
There is <cite id="4">no documented theory of change</cite> or third-party evaluation to verify the long-term educational outcomes of its literature distribution.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization provides audited financials but does not have a full BBB Wise Giving Alliance accreditation.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The foundation maintains high liquidity which mitigates short-term risks from declining revenue.
risk_factors: <cite id="2">Board size of 2 members</cite> limits independent oversight
<cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of -4.1%</cite> indicates declining funding
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="2">governance risks</cite> due to a small board and a <cite id="2">negative revenue growth trend</cite>.

confidence.notes: Strong financial efficiency but governance and impact data are lacking.

alignment.explanation: The organization has a <cite id="5">strong fit for Muslim donors</cite> as it is <cite id="5">zakat-eligible</cite> and serves the <cite id="5">fisabilillah asnaf</cite> category.

credibility.explanation: The foundation is an established institution <cite id="1">founded in 2003</cite> with <cite id="3">audited financial statements</cite> available for review. However, credibility is tempered by a <cite id="2">small two-person board</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the foundation should <cite id="2">expand its board of directors</cite> to include more independent members and publish an annual impact report.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="2">89.3% program expense ratio</cite>, though it lacks <cite id="4">verified beneficiary counts</cite> to calculate cost-effectiveness.
impact.improvement: The foundation could improve its impact score by <cite id="4">tracking and reporting specific beneficiary numbers</cite> across its digital and physical distribution channels.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Financial audits present but no outcome tracking

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct program implementation rather than grantmaking

rich_narrative.headline: Al-Furqaan Foundation is a religious non-profit dedicated to educating the American public about the core principles of Islam through large-scale distribution of literature and community outreach.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize the distribution of Islamic literature and want to support zakat-eligible dawah efforts with high financial efficiency.
donor_motivations: Want to support the distribution of the Quran to non-Muslims
Value high program expense ratios and low executive pay
Interested in niche outreach like prison dawah or Braille materials
giving_considerations: The organization has a declining revenue trend over the last three years
Donors should be comfortable with a very small governance board
Impact is measured by output (books distributed) rather than behavioral change
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-growth organizations or those who require rigorous academic evidence of social impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects the presence of <cite id="3">audited financial outputs</cite> like book distribution values, but a lack of <cite id="4">external impact evaluations</cite>.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The foundation operates on the premise that increasing access to accurate Islamic literature will counter negative stereotypes and educate the public.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence helps ensure that literature distribution actually leads to increased understanding and community cohesion.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Declining revenue trends suggest the organization has significant capacity to absorb new donations to restore previous program scales.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Maintains a <cite id="2">89.3% program ratio</cite>, significantly higher than the <cite id="1">peer median of 81.7%</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Similar size and focus on K-12 education
similar_organizations.name: Islamic Educational Foundation

similar_organizations.differentiator: Similar focus on religious services and outreach
similar_organizations.name: Dawat-E-Islami USA

strengths.detail: The foundation directs <cite id="2">89.3% of its total expenses</cite> toward its educational and outreach programs, exceeding the <cite id="1">peer program ratio median of 81.7%</cite>.
The organization spends only <cite id="1">$0.01 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions, maximizing the impact of every dollar donated.
With <cite id="1">25.1 months of working capital</cite> held in working capital, the foundation is well-positioned to survive economic fluctuations.

strengths_deep_dive: Al-Furqaan Foundation's financial health is characterized by high efficiency and low overhead. According to its <cite id="2">2020 Form 990</cite>, the organization successfully managed <cite id="2">$3,249,437 in revenue</cite> while keeping administrative costs low. Its <cite id="3">audited financials from 2019</cite> highlight a significant <cite id="3">book distribution value of $855,697</cite>, underscoring the scale of its physical literature outreach. Furthermore, the foundation has diversified its reach through digital platforms and specialized services such as <cite id="4">online products and prison outreach</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: founded in 2003, Al-Furqaan Foundation is a religious non-profit dedicated to educating the American public about Islam through literature distribution and community outreach. The organization operates several flagship initiatives, including the <cite id="4">Furqaan Project and The Clear Islam</cite>, which focus on providing accessible translations of the Quran. Financially, the foundation manages <cite id="2">$3,249,437 in total revenue</cite>, with a significant portion derived from <cite id="2">$2,073,542 in public contributions</cite>. A key differentiator for the foundation is its high operational efficiency, maintaining a <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 89.3%</cite>. This ensures that the vast majority of donor funds are directed toward its core mission, which includes specialized programs like <cite id="4">Dawah in Braille and Islam in Prison</cite>. Despite its long operational history, the foundation maintains a lean administrative structure, evidenced by <cite id="2">officer compensation of only $32,495</cite> for its top executive. The organization also demonstrates strong fiscal stability, holding <cite id="1">25.1 months of working capital</cite> in reserve, which provides a significant buffer for long-term program sustainability.
